ratings.comment: Professor McCoy is an amazing lecturer, he really cares and understands about the content of the course. He tells stories about his time in Vietnam researching and other fun stories! A must take teacher even if you arent a history major!

Prof McCoy gives the best lectures, and is extremely knowledgeable with great insights. His class reminds me about the beauty of History and Humanities curriculum in general. There are no slides so lectures can get hard to follow but he provides great outlines ahead of time. If you are a serious History major, McCoy's class is a shame to miss.
Phenomenal history professor. Old style lecturing, but very enjoyable. 11/10; would recommend.

just take the class, he's fantastic. especially recommend for history majors - you'll learn a lot about how to study history in addition to getting a fairly nuanced and thorough portrayal of the topic at hand.

I have taken all of Al McCoy's classes at UW Madison and he has been my favorite professor here. His lectures are information packed, and his classes are pretty demanding, but his instructions are clear and his TA's are awesome and will work with the students to lessen workloads and make it manageable. Midterm, paper, and final are all essays.

Prof. McCoy is by far the best professor I ever had. Incredibly knowledgeable and interesting to listen to, but you have to work for an A. Lots of reading with 2 major papers as the bulk of the grade and you have to watch the lectures/ take notes to do well on the lecture quizzes which were very specific. Seriously a disservice not to take him

Dude is a total encyclopedia, his lectures may have been the most interesting I have seen at UW. He occasionally goes off on anecdotes pretty loosely related to the class, but they're so fun I can't even be mad about it. I took this course during Covid, the lecture quizzes and final were pretty tough but the discussion and final exam were easy.

McCoy is an extremely knowledgable historian. His lectures are PACKED with information. He is sort of a monolith on campus - very well known in the history department and beyond. Although this year was odd because of the pandemic, I felt that his assignments appealed too much to his ego. Smart person, but doesn't seem to care a lot about students.

I'm pretty surprised by the confusion in some comments. The guy has crazy levels of info in lectures, but you get outlines with the main points in question form on top of each. Incredibly knowledgeable lecturer. Makes confusing things understandable. Absolutely no slant in view, providing the ideology and view from all sides. Very helpful TA too!
Very knowledgeable on Vietnam and the war, but being a Vietnam War protester, just know that you will be getting a rather slanted view of the war as a whole.

Professor McCoy is an absolute genius and expert in Vietnam War history. He brings history to life with his lectures and personal experience in Vietnam. He is funny and makes being in class interesting. Sometimes lectures can be a bit hard to follow, but he provides lecture outlines to help with that. Take his class if you have a chance !!

I really wanted to like this class but came away feeling disappointed. McCoy is so full of information it was often hard to tell what was big picture and what was just fun facts. I'm not sure what I was supposed to come away with. There is also so much reading for this class, it's unbelievable, like 200+ pages a week.

Weirdly enough, I wish he had lectured more. The class was seminar based, but he set it up badly. He had two students give lectures every week and then we didn't actually discuss anything because the student given lectures were so long. McCoy is a brilliant professor, but the class was badly structured. Easy A though & I learned a lot, just boring

Professor McCoy is by far my favorite lecturer at UW-Madison. The man knows his material and you can tell he has a true passion for the subject matter.  Expect old-school fast paced lectures (AKA, no powerpoints), but those lectures are top notch. I was always excited to go to class just to hear him speak. One midterm, one final, and 15 page paper.

Best lecturer I've heard at UW. He has actually met many of the figures he speaks of and describes them. Excellent anecdotes - sometimes funny, sometimes shocking. Papers actually improve your writing skills. I wasn't expecting much from this class but ended up really enjoying it. Would recommend for anyone even vaguely interested in history.

McCoy is the best professor I've had at UW and is an incredibly interesting lecturer.  Notes can be hard to take, but his method of lecturing makes it so you can usually understand main themes, which is what's really important.  Very relevant class and vividly dissects the Vietnam War's causes and effects.  Would absolutely take again.

McCoy is the best professor I've had at UW and I wish I would have taken his other classes. He expects high level thought, and my guess is the people below had no interest in intellectually challenging themselves. He is the world expert on the CIA in SE Asia, the Philippines and CIA torture. You do yourself a huge disservice by not taking his class

Lectures were a little hard to follow unless you used the outline McCoy provided to follow along. I would recommend recording the lectures as McCoy tends to lecture without rest so it's  challenging to try and take notes. This class is graded on one written midterm, discussion section, one research paper, and a written final.

The topic of Vietnam is extremely relevant to any American citizen because the after effects of the war have been so profound. Alfred McCoy speaks as one of the great Roman orators, telling the tragedy of a great republic, bringing the class to tears and laughter. Highly recommend this class. Books are a bit left-leaning but overall very factual.

Professor McCoy is a great lecturer! His lectures are organized very well and he follows his outlines to a key. If you take this class, make sure you dont get a discussion section with T.A.  Sinae Hyun. She is ridiculous, expects more than is reasonable for a 300 level class. Has no sympathy and has an arrogant aura. Very Poor.Doesn't represent UW

The best lecturer on campus, McCoys uncanny charisma makes nearly every lecture captivating! Fast pace but his knowledge and the content used, are unsurpassed, most I've learned in a college course yet! If you enjoy history take this class, you will not regret it. Anecdotes moved me to tears and I'm a guy.  I would take it again in a heartbeat!

By far the best professor I've had at UW. I look forward to getting to his class each week because it's that good to hear the man talk. Be ready to read a lot, but lectures are fascinating and grading is pretty fair considering the work load. Take it!

Lectures incredibly fast and a lot of readings, but they can easily be skimmed. Grades are based on a paper and two essay exams. I went to lecture about once a month and still got an A (lecture material goes by so fast it's almost impossible to take notes, and 99% of what he says won't be necessary for the exams). Exams are based on readings.

If you enjoy history and are willing to put in some work, you will enjoy this class. McCoy seems intimidating, but really has his students' best interests at heart. Lectures are old-fashioned (no Powerpoints, just lots of information being yelled at you) so expect to take lots of notes.  Also expect lots of reading. He is very interesting.

There is a massive amount of reading, and he lectures very quickly.  I would not recommend this class to anyone, ever.  He is really interesting and very intelligent, but the class is tough.  DO NOT TAKE IT.

Stern man, but not a bad guy.  Class was fascinating, he really is an expert in the field.  If you don't take notes well all the material is covered well in the books.  Expect to go get a giant stack of musty books from the library though.

EXTREMELY interesting/thought-provoking (intense) class. Lectures are confusing has real life anecdotes and delivery that is unmatched. This class is very difficult w/ tons of rdgs (I mean more than I've ever read before for class), rigorous material & concepts & covers ALL of SEA; found it overwhelming for SEA newbie. NOT EASY/should b grad level
He knows EVERYTHING about Vietnam and the war.  Great professor, great lectures, but they won't help much on midterm and final...
Very interesting course.  It is a lot of work, and fairly difficult, but well worth it!

i've done more reading for this one class than i've done some entire semesters at wisconsin...seriously, you will read about 8000 pages of text...and you will lose track of how it all ties in together, but you will learn, and you will learn how to learn.  for those aspiring history phds this is one class you dont want to miss out on.

Knows everything there is to know. Shares his opinion but usually makes it obvious. Looked forward to every lecture. Blazing fast lectures, agree with comment about laptops being critical. Lots of reading, some dry much fascinating.
I was completely lost most of the class. Difficult to know which details are important. Somehow I managed to escape with an A, so if you're feeling the same way, there is hope!

The single best professor I have had. Shares incredible anecdotes about his experiences and has done so much research and is devoted to the subject. Extremely fast lectures; so far the only class I have truly needed my laptop for. Take this class.

This professor's lecturing style is difficult to get used to, and the first half of the semester sucks, but after that, it gets great. The information is so interesting, and although the class can get long, his stories and his experiences are incredible. HOWEVER, if you have Ruth as a TA, switch to another TA. She's the worst TA I have ever had.

Easily a top prof at UW, teaches what he knows/loves and it shows. He's arguably the best speaker at UW; lectures are interesting, clearly organized, and he has a great sense of humor. Had him last semester. Great class, not hard, but don't expect to coast. Do the readings the TA's point out and you'll be fine for the midterm/paper. Al's the man.

One of the best classes I have taken at UW. Sure, the research paper blows, but I can't believe how much I learned! His lectures are fast paced, but very captivating with tons of personal anecdotes. Don't be discouraged by the first month of class-it gets better!

By far the best class I have ever taken.  McCoy is inspiring and a great lecturer.  Sure he lecturers a little fast, but the content is invaluable.  Furthermore, it exposed the CIA to opium trafficking in mainland Southeast Asia, as well as changed an election in the Philippines by exposing the president re-running for office.  Best prof I ever had

Simply, the most inspiring professor I've had.  The last lecture had everyone captivated and there were even a few tears in the room.  You have to suffer through the beginning of the course but the ending makes it all worth it!

He likes to talk. A lot. Fast. But the material is REALLY interesting. His experiences add depth to what he's talking about b/c of their uhh colorful nature. The only problem was getting lost during lecture because he jumps around sometimes and just barrels through everything. I took at least five pages 1 sided of notes every time. MAGSAYSAY MAMBO!
Great teacher. Class is not that hard but try and stay away from the female TA

Takes some time to get used to his rapid lecturing style, but you don't have to copy down every minute detail.  If you're lucking for a professor to baby you with power points, this is the wrong class to take.  Exams and research paper are very fair; you're basically in control of your grade if you take good notes and synthesize the readings well.

You have to do the reading in this course-especially from the Young book but it is definently possible to do well. The midterm is take home and he gives you a pretty good idea of what the final will be. the first stuff is sort of boring but he doesnt test you on it anyway
Seriously: why do people like this guy?!?!  I guess he's a nice person but the course sucked ... Also, he is not at all accessible outside of class ...

Whoa. This guy has seen and done alot unlike some of the other blowhard liberals on campus who have co-opted the "truth".  If you can, take any class with this prof but be ready to work hard and be held to a higher standard.

There's no doubt that this guy knows his Vietnam stuff.  But the fact is, he's way too fast in lecture, and it takes far too long to get to the more interesting topics in the class.  I was really interested in this class, especially after reading other people's reviews, but I'd have to deem it the most overrated class at Madison.  Extremely tough!

Absolutely amazing professor.  Papers are challenging, but I wouldn't say tough.  You will learn so much even if you don't read, but I would encourage reading the Young book, along with his (there's a totally badass picture of him on the back).  McCoy is THE expert on CIA covert ops.  This is one of the best classes the university has to offer.
Very good professor, his class is hard but you learn a lot and he teaches you in a way that you will know the material when you leave.  Extraordinary expierences with this era. Highly regarded.
Very knowledgeable, but very confusing in lecture, goes a million miles an hour
Extraordinary professor!  He's tough, but in a way that actually improves the student.  You come out of his classes feeling like you really accomplished something.  One of my favorite professors.
One of the best classes I've ever taken; Period.
Best class ever and best teacher ever!!  He opened my eyes to research, reading and history.  If there ever were a class I recommend anyone take, it's the Vietnam Wars; you will never regret it.
AMAZING PROFESSOR! AMAZING CLASS!
Very smart and good at leading discussion sessions.  His classes were challenging, but were my favorite while I was a student at UW.
